awd_titl_txt: ERI: Investigate the Role of Affect in Fostering Trust in Automated Driving
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

This Engineering Research Initiation (ERI) grant will support research that will contribute new knowledge related to the role of affect in trust in automated driving, promoting the relationships between human drivers and automated vehicles. The human mind has the affective and cognitive components. So does trust in automation, but affect is the primary determinant of trusting behavior. However, studies of affect on trust in automation are scarce. Therefore, it is critical to examine the role of affect in trust in automated vehicles. The overall objective of the project is to explore the role of affect in trust-based interaction in automated driving. In order to attain the overall objective, three integrated aims will be pursued, i.e., 1) build real-time trust prediction models using psychophysiological measures, 2) investigate the relations between affect and trust in automated vehicles, and 3) calibrate trust in automated vehicles using affect heuristics.  Once relevant psychophysiological measures are identified, they can be used to build real-time trust prediction models and once the relationships between the latent structure of affect in trust-based interaction and trust in AVs are identified and the real-time trust prediction model is built, affect can help build and calibrate driver trust in AVs using affect heuristics. Hence, the results from this research will promote the progress of science and national health (e.g., preventing crashes) by advancing our understanding of bidirectional trust-based interaction in automated driving and beyond.
 
First, this research will build real-time trust prediction models using psychophysiological measures, which can overcome the limitations of previous research that mainly measured trust once at the end of a session or twice as pre- and post- levels of trust, which did not reflect the dynamic nature of trust in automation. Second, this research will investigate the relations between affect and trust in automated vehicles by examining the latent structure of affective responses related to trust in automated driving and how affective responses are related to different aspects of trust. Third, this research will examine the role of affect by making use of affect heuristic in automated driving measured by both self-reported and psychophysiological data. Such research endeavors will help understand the role of affect in trust in automated driving.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As self-driving cars, or automated vehicles (AVs), become more common, ensuring people trust them appropriately - not too much and not too little - is crucial for safety and acceptance. This project, funded by the National Science Foundation, explored how human trust in AVs develops and changes, focusing particularly on the often-overlooked role of our emotions (affect) alongside factors like vehicle performance and perceived risk. The goal was to gain a deeper understanding that could lead to safer and more user-friendly AVs.

To achieve this, we conducted studies using driving simulators where university students interacted with AVs in various scenarios. Sometimes the simulated AV performed perfectly, while other times it made errors (like needing help in a construction zone or giving wrong information). Participants' trust levels were measured both through questionnaires and, significantly, by exploring the potential of using real-time body signals (physiological measures like heart rate, galvanic skin response, and eye movements). We also investigated how pre-existing ideas about AV risk and participants' emotional reactions (like confidence, anxiety, or frustration) influenced trust. Advanced analysis, including machine learning and statistical modeling, helped us identify patterns and understand the complex relationships between these factors.

Our research yielded several key outcomes across the project's lifespan:

  1. Real-Time Trust Prediction Using Physiological Signals (Aim 1): We successfully demonstrated that it's possible to predict a driver's level of trust in an AV in real-time using their physiological signals. By feeding data like heart rate changes, skin conductivity, and eye-tracking patterns into machine learning models (specifically, one called XGBoost), we could predict trust with high accuracy (an F1-score of 89.1%). This is important because it offers an objective way to monitor trust without constantly interrupting the driver, opening possibilities for future AVs that could adapt to the driver's state.

  2. Identification of Distinct Driver Trust Profiles (Aim 2): We discovered that people fall into different categories based on how they trust AVs. We identified three distinct "trust profiles":

    • Confident Copilots: Generally trust AVs, stay positive even after errors, and value the convenience.

    • Myopic Pragmatists: Trust level swings rapidly based on the AV's most recent actions – high trust after success, low trust and frustration after errors.

    • Reluctant Automators: Start with low trust, prefer control, feel more anxious, and need to understand how the AV works to build trust.
      We validated these profiles statistically and showed they are linked to personality traits and emotional patterns.

  3. Understanding the Drivers of Trust - Experience and Emotion (Aim 3): We found that a driver's direct experience with the AV (witnessing its performance, good or bad) had a much stronger impact on their trust than any pre-conceived notions about AV risks. Furthermore, emotions played a critical role in bridging performance and trust. Specifically:

    • Feeling Confident in the AV (which increased significantly with error-free performance) was the most powerful factor leading to higher trust.

    • Reduced feelings of Hostility and Anxiety (also resulting from good performance) contributed to increased trust as well.

These findings have significant real-world impacts. The ability to predict trust in real-time (Aim 1) provides a foundation for future adaptive AV systems that could adjust their behavior or communication based on the driver's state. Understanding the different trust profiles (Aim 2) allows designers to create AVs that better cater to diverse user needs and preferences (e.g., providing more explanations for 'Reluctant Automators'). The confirmation that reliable performance and fostering confidence are paramount (Aim 3) gives clear direction to engineers and designers prioritizing safety and user acceptance. This research contributes valuable knowledge for developing AV technology that is not only capable but also effectively integrates with human users, fostering appropriate trust for safer roads. The project also provided crucial advanced research training for three PhD students and two master students, and the results have been disseminated through publications in leading peer-reviewed journals (including IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems and IEEE Transactions on Human-Machine Systems) and conference presentations.
